div.head: REFLECTIONS ON The CASE of ALLEGIANCE to a King in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and The Defence of it.
div.p:
IF I could be unea≈øy under any of your Commands, this, you may be a≈ø≈øured, would be the time of my ≈øhewing it: It is an hard task you have laid upon me; The Books, of which you require my thoughts, are long: and ≈øpeak the Author (whoever he is) to be a Man of great Learning and Rea≈øon; one, who can argue to the be≈øt advantage his Subject will bear. And the Collections he has made, plainly ≈øhew, that he has taken great pains, and bent all his thoughts for ≈øome time, to the maintenance of that Cau≈øe, to which ≈øome Prejudice has unhappily determined him. I, Sir, to your knowledg never ≈øaw the Books till within the≈øe very few days, and I fear you will have too much rea≈øon from what I write to believe me, when I tell you, That the reading the Books once over, (and that with frequent Interruptions too) wa≈øted almo≈øt half the time I have been able to allow my thoughts upon the Subject. This has prevented my con≈øulting any Books written
in favour of Submi≈ø≈øion to a King in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, nay, of reading Dr. Sherlock's Book, which the Defence pretends to An≈øwer. You mu≈øt not therefore be ≈øuprized, if you happen to meet here with what others have ≈øaid on the ≈øame Subject, without any acknowledgment that I received it from them; or (which I more fear) if you ≈øhould find Opinions differing from tho≈øe of very great Men, who have undertaken this Controver≈øy. They were my Thoughts, Sir, which you required, and I have taken a cour≈øe to give them to you free, neither bia≈ø≈øed, nor over-ruled by the Opinions or Authority of others.

The Que≈øtion, as 'tis ≈øtated by the Author of the Ca≈øe, is put very cautiou≈øly and ≈øtrongly in favour of the Cau≈øe he propo≈øes to him≈øelf to maintain; he has fenced it in with ≈øuch Re≈øtrictions in the ≈øtating, and the Expo≈øition of the Terms, that it would be a very unnece≈ø≈øary thing to undertake an An≈øwer to him, if his Book did not offer at the proof of more than the fir≈øt Que≈øtion under his Limitations, does require from him.

No one, I ≈øuppo≈øe, who has ≈øubmitted to Their Maje≈øties Government, who thinks it too the Duty of all Engli≈øh Men to do the ≈øame, and to pay Faith and Allegiance to them, will therefore believe him≈øelf at all concerned to maintain that, If a Per≈øon who has no manner of Right, by force, exclude, or depo≈øe a King, who≈øe Right to the Crown is clear and undoubted, and thereby gets the Exerci≈øe of the Government into his hands, the Regal Authority, and undoubted Right remaining ≈øtill in the excluded Prince, the People ought to pay a full and entire Submi≈ø≈øion and Obedience to this King in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, ≈øo as never to attempt any thing again≈øt him, but ≈øtand by and defend him again≈øt the di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Prince, with his Life and Fortune. This is a Ca≈øe of our Author's own making, and bears no Re≈øemblance
to the pre≈øent State of this Nation: Nay, on the contrary, if I may take the liberty to reduce the general Que≈øtion to our particular Ca≈øe, I think the two things agreed by him, as Preliminaries, will ≈øufficiently ju≈øtify any Engli≈øh Man in his ≈øwearing Allegiance, and paying the Duty Ca≈øe, f. 2. of a Subject to Their pre≈øent Maje≈øties. For the fir≈øt of them agrees, That a bare Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, tho purely by ∆≤≈øurpation, will carry a Right to the Subjects Allegiance in an Hereditary Monarchy, where the whole Royal Line is extinct; to prevent the Blood≈øhed and Confu≈øion which might follow upon the Peoples attempting to ≈øet up another Per≈øon or Government. This prudential Rea≈øon, and a Submi≈ø≈øion upon it, he lays down to be a ≈øufficient Title to the U≈øurper, and that it makes him from thenceforth King de Jure, one to whom all Faith and Allegiance becomes due. ('Tis ≈øo obvious of it ≈øelf, that I might ≈øpare the ob≈øerving, That he frames his Ca≈øe upon a Suppo≈øition of the whole Royal Lines being extinct, for no other purpo≈øe than to re≈øtrain it ≈øo, as to extend only to Ca≈øes where there is no other Per≈øon in being, who has a ju≈øt Title to the Crown, and who≈øe Right is invaded by that Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion).
The ≈øecond agrees, That where there are divers pretenders, and it is not clear who has the true Right or Title; the Subjects Allegiance is to follow the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

If therefore the late King, by the a≈ø≈øuming to him≈øelf an Authority to ≈øu≈øpend, and by general and unlimited Di≈øpen≈øations to repeal Laws without Parliament; by the entru≈øting almo≈øt the whole Power, Military and Civil, in the hands of ≈øuch Per≈øons only as would undertake with their endeavours to ≈øupport him in tho≈øe Exce≈ø≈øes; By the putting tho≈øe few Laws which he found it his intere≈øt to ob≈øerve, in Execution, by ≈øuch generally, as were by Law made incapable of all Tru≈øt and Rule; By the con≈øtant
aim and tendency that every one of his Actions had to en≈ølave us at home, not to omit the Bonds prepared for us, by his immoveable Adherence to the Intere≈øts of the French King, from which (as a chargeable Experience teaches us) the utmo≈øt effort we can make, and that a≈ø≈øi≈øted with very great and powerful Alliances, will ≈øcarce re≈øcue us. If his unwearied endeavours to de≈øtroy the Reformed Religion, with a thou≈øand other Male-Admini≈øtrations, that ≈øtruck at the very Being and Foundation of the Con≈øtitution it ≈øelf, and the Laws and Liberties of the People of England; did declare, that he would not govern by our Laws or Act by an Authority limited by them. If upon the Parliaments humble and mode≈øt Repre≈øentation to him (according to their Duty) of the unwarrantablene≈øs of ≈øuch Proceedings, and the Alarm that the People took at his great Violations of their Rights, and Breaches upon the Government, he broke them up in Anger, and thereby ≈øhewed an ob≈øtinate and ≈øetled Re≈øolution to a≈ø≈øert that unlimited Power to him≈øelf, and govern according to it. If having by the≈øe Arbitrary Proceedings drawn great Difficulties upon him≈øelf, in≈øtead of taking proper Cour≈øes to ≈øecure his People again≈øt ≈øuch Exce≈ø≈øes for the future, he held to the ≈øame Coun≈øels ≈øtill, and by their Advice quitted the Kingdom, then in the utmo≈øt Confu≈øion, without making any Provi≈øion for the Admini≈øtration of the Government, and voluntarily put him≈øelf into the hands of its avowed perpetual Enemy. If all the≈øe things put together, will amount, either to a renouncing and di≈øclaiming his Title to a Government limited by Laws, or a di≈øabling and rendring him incapable to Exerci≈øe any Government at all. Nay, If the ≈øhare and intere≈øt which the Body of the People have in the Pre≈øervation of the Laws and Con≈øtitution, and their concern in the welfare of the whole,
will make it come up but to a doubtful Ca≈øe. If upon this, to re≈øcue us from tho≈øe Confu≈øions, to pre≈øerve what remained of the Ancient Government, and to re≈øtore what had been impaired, the Repre≈øentatives of the People did fill the de≈øerted Throne by proclaiming the Authors of our Deliverance, King and Queen, and the Body of the People (for the number of Male-contents is ≈øo incon≈øiderable, that there is no need of ≈øoftning the word upon their account) have owned their Title to the Crown, ≈øubmitted and ≈øworn Allegiance to them as their Governors: And if it be vi≈øible to the whole World, that their Government has produced all the good Effects that were propo≈øed or aimed at, and they are in as full and quiet Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Throne, as ever any Princes were who ≈øat upon it, with a repeated Recognition of their Title. I cannot but think, that every one, who will give him≈øelf leave calmly to con≈øider, mu≈øt agree, That our Ca≈øe comes up to that which our Author puts. It does not, cannot appear that any other Per≈øon has a better Right to the Crown: and the con≈øequence of our Author's drawing from that, will be, That every Engli≈øh-man ought to bear Faith, and pay Allegiance to Their Maje≈øties, who (thanks be to God) are in ≈øo full a Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Throne.

But not to enter farther into the general Que≈øtion, which, I think, ought not to be too freely ≈øearcht into, le≈øt it give Advantage and Encouragement to a ≈øort of People, who will be forward out of Wantonne≈øs, to put things in practice, which nothing but the utmo≈øt nece≈ø≈øity can ju≈øtifie; I conceive I ≈øhall effectually an≈øwer all that can be materially objected from the Ca≈øe of Allegiance, &c. and the Defence of it, again≈øt our pre≈øent Settlement, if I can maintain this Propo≈øition‚ñ™
That where a King is in the full and quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Throne, and Exerci≈øe of the Government; has been ≈øolemnly proclaimed, and freely and voluntarily recognized and ≈øubmitted unto by the States of the Kingdom as their King; has vi≈øibly the Power and Strength of the Nation in his hands; the Laws have their due cour≈øe in his Name, and all publick ju≈øtice is admini≈øtred by tho≈øe deputed and commi≈ø≈øionated by him; altho he had no precedent legal Right, and that there is another per≈øon living, who according to the ordinary cour≈øe of Hereditary Succe≈ø≈øion, has a ju≈øt claim to the Crown; yet the Laws of England do require every private ≈øubject to pay their Allegiance to ≈øuch a King in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and protect them in their ≈øo doing. And this, I hope, will be fully made out, by plain Law, and all the ≈øeeming Objections offered again≈øt it from the Laws of the Land, an≈øwered.

To ≈øave my ≈øelf and the Reader ≈øome trouble hereafter, it will be convenient, before I enter into the particular con≈øideration of our Author's Arguments and Objections, to ob≈øerve, That the Government of England is to be con≈øidered in two re≈øpects: 1≈øt, With regard to the Power of Legi≈ølature, viz. The King and Body of the States, who have power over all po≈øitive Laws, to make new ones according as they in their Judgments ≈øhall think expedient, and to alter, amend, and ≈øupply the defects of the old ones, as they in prudence ≈øhall judg the pre≈øent circum≈øtances of Affairs require. 2ly, The Executive Power, of which the King is ≈øupreme, and Courts of Ju≈øtice, and other Officers ≈øubordinate under him. To them it belongs not to deliberate or determine, what in their opinions it were fit or rea≈øonable the Law ≈øhould be, and thereupon declare that to be Law; but to declare what the Law is, as it at pre≈øent ≈øtands, in every ca≈øe coming judicially before them, and to put that
Law in Execution. This is ≈øo very obvious, that it mu≈øt without he≈øitation be agreed to me; and ≈øo mu≈øt the con≈øequence that I draw from it: That I need not make it any part of the pre≈øent Que≈øtion, Whether the Acts of one who is called an U≈øurper in Title, that tend immediately to the de≈øtruction of the right of the di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Prince, be ju≈øt in them≈øelves, ≈øo that they ought to continue in force, and not be repealed and annulled, by a Power competent for that purpo≈øe, upon the injured Prince's happening to be re≈øtored to his Right: But whether ≈øuch Acts being done according to the known legal Forms and Ceremonies, by ≈øuch a Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor of the Throne as I have before de≈øcribed, every private ≈øubject may not, in good Con≈øcience, ≈øubmit unto and obey them, without taking upon him to judge of his Governour's Title? Nay further, whether the Laws of the Land do not protect him in ≈øo doing; and not only ≈øo, but require it from him?
I think the Affirmative is agreeable to the Laws: And I now come to con≈øider what our Author ≈øays to the contrary.

The fir≈øt Point he endeavours to make out, is, That notwith≈øtanding the Opinions of the Eminent Lawyers whom he mentions (which I mu≈øt ob≈øerve were delivered in the times of Kings, who≈øe Titles to the Crown were undoubted, ≈øo that there was no nece≈ø≈øity for their ≈øtraining the ≈øen≈øe of the Law to make it favour their Ma≈øter's intere≈øt: and which, for ought that ever yet has appeared, were never contradicted hitherto by any one of that profe≈ø≈øion), A King de facto is not Seignior le Roy within the Statute of 25 E. 3.

I ≈øhall through this Di≈øcour≈øe take tho≈øe words to mean, one who is in the full and peaceable po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Throne, and Exerci≈øe of the Government, with
the free ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion of the People, by their Repre≈øentatives a≈ø≈øembled in a Parliamentary way; but wants a Title by proximity of Blood and Hereditary Succe≈ø≈øion; and undertake for the defence of the duty of Allegiance to ≈øuch an one only, and not to any po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion without a true Right, ≈øhort of that: If any of the proofs which I ≈øhall make u≈øe of hereafter, ≈øhall carry it further, they will more ≈øtrongly prove this: But I will not an≈øwer for more.

I ob≈øerve in general upon this Statute, 1. That the puni≈øhment pre≈øcribed by it, for the offences now under debate, is the utmo≈øt to which a temporal Law can reach, Death and Di≈øgrace: This will make it highly rea≈øonable, that the offence ≈øhould be plain and certain. And in the ≈øecond place, That this Statute was made in favour of the Subject, that he might be at a certainty what hazards he runs, and not be ≈øwallowed up in the Gulf, before he apprehended him≈øelf to be beyond his Banks: It made no new offence, but was re≈øtrictive of the liberty that Judges had taken before, of expounding every thing, that an angry or jealous Prince did re≈øent as a wound of his Maje≈øty, into High Trea≈øon. This is ≈øo well known to all that have lookt into the Law, that it were idle to quote Authorities for it. I will, add in the third place, as a thing not improper to be ob≈øerved, That it would be a very hard thing before E. 3's time to prove a certain Hereditary Succe≈ø≈øion. The be≈øt Hi≈øtorian will find but few In≈øtances of that kind from the Conque≈øt till the time of the making of this Statute. So that the defect of Hereditary Title, could not be a thing forgotten, or ≈ølipt over, as out of the minds of King or People: Yet I can't perceive any thing in this Statute, to lead to ≈øuch a di≈øtinction as is now made; tho it was made as a Rule for the Subject, from which he might learn, how
he might demean him≈øelf in tho≈øe great matters with ≈øafety‚ñ™ There is not ≈øo much as an Hint, that the trying who has the ju≈øt Right and Title to the Crown, whether He, who is owned by the States of the Kingdom, and has the full Government and admini≈øtration of all Affairs; or another, who a thoughtful bu≈øie man (that can't content him≈øelf in the private ≈øtation wherein God Almighty has placed him, but mu≈øt make him≈øelf a Judge of the highe≈øt matters) will be fancying ought to be there. I ≈øay, That the trying that Point, ≈øhould be left to a Jury of 12 men; as it mu≈øt be, ≈øhould a private per≈øon be proceeded again≈øt for an attempt upon the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor, in order to the re≈øtoring the di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Prince; If it be true, that it is not Trea≈øon by that Law, for a private Subject to attempt any thing again≈øt the King in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, in behalf of him, that of Right, by Hereditary Succe≈ø≈øion, ought to be King.

This would be an hard Interpretation of a Statute, made in the time of a King who obtained po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Kingdom by a War levied again≈øt his Father, and a forced Re≈øignation, after the Arms, of tho≈øe who took part with him, were ≈øucce≈øsful: In which taking up Arms again≈øt the King in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, notwith≈øtanding all that might ju≈øtifie it in Rea≈øon of State and Prudence, he was ≈øen≈øible that the Laws of the Land would not bear his friends out; and therefore thought fit, in the fir≈øt year of his Reign, to have an Act of Parliament pa≈ø≈øed, to indemnifie them again≈øt ordinary legal proceedings; for what they had done. This he lookt upon as nece≈ø≈øary, tho at the ≈øame time, he thought the Cau≈øe in which tho≈øe who fell in the War, died, ≈øo ju≈øt in it ≈øelf, that he made a new Law on purpo≈øe, to ≈øave them from ≈øuffering in their E≈øtates: For we find, in the ≈øame year, there was a Statute made, to entitle the Executors of tho≈øe, who
were Slain in his Quarrel, in the pur≈øuit again≈øt his Father, to Actions to recover their Te≈øtators Goods.

Lawyers account Co-temporaneam Expo≈øitionem, the be≈øt interpreter of the Sen≈øe of Statute-laws. I would fain have the Author, or any one el≈øe, who would confine the words Seignior le Roy in that Statute, to, Lawful and Rightful King by Hereditary Succe≈ø≈øion only, to ≈øhew any thing leading to that Interpretation in the Hi≈øtory of that time, or any of the Kings Reigns before that. Where it was ever heard of before that Act, that Allegiance was due to the uncrowned, un≈øubmitted-unto Right Heir? Nay, I will go farther, Where in any publick Record, before that Statute, there does appear a damning of the Title of ≈øuch a King, after a Submi≈ø≈øion of the People to him, in favour of him that was nearer in Blood? Whether the ≈øeveral Predece≈ø≈øors of E. 3. who had not a legal Title by Hereditary Succe≈ø≈øion, are not called Kings, in the Statutes of almo≈øt every year of his Reign, and all their Acts unque≈øtioned? If there were nothing extant to direct the Subjects to the contrary, and the King him≈øelf ≈øo often told them, that tho≈øe, whom I mu≈øt call Kings de Facto only, were Kings without any addition (the very letter of this Statute) it would in≈øtead of being an Ea≈øe and Relief to the People, have proved according to the pre≈øent Interpretation, the greate≈øt Snare that was po≈ø≈øible.

'Twas ea≈øy for them to ≈øee and know who exerci≈øed the Kingly Office, under who≈øe Admini≈øtration they had the benefit of the Laws, and by who≈øe Authority all Judicial Proceedings took their Cour≈øe. They might too, without any great difficulty, learn who were the vi≈øible Attendants on the Throne, the
King's near Relations, his Wife, Son, and Daughter. The Throne is but one, and they ≈øaw who po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed that. The name King, is a name of Office, which con≈øi≈øts in Exerci≈øe, that too was as plain to them. The words of the Statute ≈øeem as plain, 'Tis Trea≈øon to compa≈øs or imagine the Death, &c. of the King: Would it not now be a very great hard≈øhip to put it upon a private Per≈øon, to ≈øeek an hidden Sen≈øe in plain Words, and at the peril of his Life and Family, to make him≈øelf judge of all the Difficulties which may ari≈øe upon our Con≈øtitution, (which, what it is in all points, never was or will be agreed upon)? Whether this Per≈øon that is ≈øo expre≈øly within the words of the Statute, may not hereafter appear to have been wrongfully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed: And upon that apprehen≈øion, to put the poor Man under an Obligation of laying him≈øelf, for the ≈øake of a Nation, open to the Vengeance of one, who has the plain words of the Law on his ≈øide, and Power to back it?
